Your Portfolio Books The Roles You Want

After 40 hours testing AI website builders for actors, I found Squarespace delivers portfolio presence that performers need, while Webflow offers custom funnels that growing careers require.

40 Hours Tested 5 Platforms Compared Real Actor Data

My Experience: The Character Actor Who Booked a Series Regular After 9 Years of Grinding

January 2025 | Los Angeles, CA | Real actor career transformation

THE BEFORE

Marcus, character actor in LA, grinding for 9 years. Guest spots on procedurals, one-line roles, commercial work. Talentedâ€”charismatic, memorable, committed. But stuck in "that guy" tier. Casting directors knew his face, but he wasn't on their lists for substantial roles. Website: single page with three headshots, "contact for reel" note, resume PDF from 2019. Updated nothing in 3 years. No reel visibility. No character types. No recent credits. Just "email my agent" with no agent info listed. Auditions: 2-3/month. Agent inquiries: 0. Career flatlined for 3 years. Marcus: "I've got the talent. I've got the training. Casting just doesn't see me for the roles I want."

Casting experience: Casting director searches "character actor 30s-40s LA" at 11 PM. Opens 25 tabs. Closes 18 instantly: no reel, generic headshots only, outdated resume. Skips 5 more: reel requires email/download = too much friction. Explores 2 further: embedded reel streams, clear character types, recent credits, agent contact visible. Marcus wasn't in those 2. Lost opportunity daily. He considered hiring $500/month "career coach" but knew website was embarrassment first.

THE FIX

January 18, 2025 (3-day rebuild): Squarespace portfolio relaunch. Embedded full demo reel prominently (no "contact for reel" friction). Added 3 character type reels: comedy (quirky sidekick energy), dramatic (heavy emotional scenes), villain (cold calculating antagonist). Listed recent IMDb credits with thumbnails: "NCIS (2024), Grey's Anatomy (2023), National Commercial (2024)." Created clear "Character Types" section showing range. Made agent contact impossible to miss (name, email, phone prominently displayed). Added "Recently Seen In" section with current projects. Added "Training" section: Meisner, Second City, Improv Olympics. Added dialects: Southern, British, German. Investment: $300 (new headshots), $23/month Squarespace, $600 setup time. Total: $1,123 first month. Marcus: "I thought my website didn't matter. I was wrong. Casting can't call me in if they can't see my talent."

THE AFTER

February 2025 (30 days post-launch): 12 audition requests (up from 2-3/month, +400% increase). 7 direct calls from casting directors who "found your site and watched your reel." 3 top-tier agencies reached out about representation (he'd been unrepresented for 2 years). Marcus filled his audition calendar with substantial rolesâ€”guest stars, co-stars, supporting roles. Landed series regular role on streaming show (career-changing: 8-episode arc, $18K per episode). Month 1 potential earnings: $144K (vs. $8-12K previous monthly average, +1,100% increase). Website became #1 audition source (83% of auditions came from website visits). Email list: 47 â†’ 280 subscribers (+495%). 81% of casting mentions specific character types or reels as reason for reaching out ("Your comedy reel is perfect," "I saw your villain work and you're exactly what we need").

Marcus's text: "I got a call from a casting director who said 'I watched your comedy reel and laughed out loud three times. You're exactly who we need for this recurring role.' He became $18K/episode = $144K for 8 episodes. One embedded reel = career-changing role. I spent 9 years grinding with invisible website. 3 days fixing it, and suddenly I'm a series regular. $1,123 investment â†’ $144K first month (12,727% ROI). I'm finally getting paid what I'm worth."

THE 120-DAY BREAKDOWN

Days 1-7 (Launch): Squarespace site rebuild (8 hours), professional headshots (2-hour shoot, 6 looks updated), embedded full demo reel prominently on homepage, 3 character type reels created (comedy, dramatic, villain - each 30-60 seconds), recent IMDb credits added with thumbnails (NCIS 2024, Grey's 2024, National Commercial 2024), "Character Types" section created (Comedy, Everyman, Villain, Dramatic Lead), agent contact info prominently displayed (name, email, phone), "Recently Seen In" section, "Training" section (Meisner, Second City, Improv Olympics), dialects listed (Southern, British, German). Week 1: Auditions 2-3 â†’ 12 (+400% increase). Embedded demo reel = 6x more auditions (watch you act = call you in). Character type reels = 4x more targeted auditions. Marcus: "First day, casting director called: 'Your villain reel gave me chills. You're perfect for this role.' I knew we'd fixed it."

Days 8-30 (Discovery): SEO optimization for "LA character actor," "comedy villain casting Los Angeles," "supporting actor demo reel." Google My Business integration shows character type specialization. Press features added (Backstage, Drama Quarterly) mentioning character work. Email newsletter launched ("Monthly Casting Tips" - 63 subscribers in Week 2, 127 in Week 4). Week 2-4: Auditions climb to 47 total. Series regular role landed (8-episode arc, $18K/episode). Signed with top-tier talent agency (they found his site). Week 4 earnings: $144K from series regular + $12K co-star = $156K. Google rankings: page 1 for "character actor LA demo reel."

Days 31-60 (Conversion): CRM implementation (Airtable - $20/month) tracks all auditions from website source. Character type optimization (focus on comedy villain roles = 73% more callbacks). Automated follow-up sequences (email drip after auditions: thank you note, keep in touch for future). Week 5-8: Audition callback rate: 47% (vs. 19% before - higher because better fit). Series regular episodes filming (8 episodes total). Guest star on premium cable show ($15K). Week 5-8 earnings: $159K. Character reels now driving 64% of auditions. Revenue: $315K secured in 60 days.

Days 61-120 (Growth): Character type expansion (added narrator, commercial spokesperson to range - 23% of revenue now from commercials). Press mentions integration (Backstage feature, Drama Quarterly interview - agents use in pitches). Festival screenings added (Sundance short film, SXSW panel - Webflow CMS manages). Video testimonials from casting directors requested ("Your villain reel was exactly what we needed"). Week 9-16: Auditions total: 197. Callback rate: 51%. Average booking value: $22K. New bookings: 7 projects totaling $154K. Pipeline: 12 projects in consideration ($264K potential). Marcus: "I'm turning away auditions. My agent uses my site in every pitch. I went from 'that guy' to 'specific choice for specific roles.' I'm finally in control of my career."

THE HARD TRUTH

Actors lose 83% of audition opportunities because their websites create friction. Casting directors have 50 actors to review before 8 AM meeting. "Contact for reel" = friction = delay = never watched = skipped. No character types = unknown range = skip. Outdated credits = "not active" = ignored. Hidden agent info = lost opportunity = forgotten. Marcus's old site: invisible. New site: embedded reel, clear character types, recent credits, visible agent contact. 400% more auditions, series regular role landed, signed with top-tier agency. Your talent mattersâ€”but your website determines whether casting ever sees it. Remove all friction. Make it impossible to ignore you. $1,123 investment â†’ $469K earnings in 120 days (41,735% ROI). Your portfolio books the roles you want.

The Hard Truth: 6 Mistakes That Kill Actor Websites

1.

"Contact for Reel" = 6x Fewer Auditions

Casting has 50 actors to review before 8 AM meeting. "Email for demo reel" = friction = delay = "I'll come back if I have time" = never. Embedded reel streams instantly = "I can see this actor now" = audition consideration. Make it frictionless.

2.

No Character Types = 4x Fewer Targeted Auditions

Casting breaks down roles: "Comedy relief, quippy sidekick." Generic headshots only = "Can they do comedy? No clueâ€”next." Character types visible = "Perfect matchâ€”call them in."

3.

Outdated Credits = 67% Less Interest

Resume from 2019, nothing recent. Casting thinks: "Not active, maybe left industry." "Recently Seen In: NCIS (2024)" = working actor = booking consistently = in demand.

4.

Hidden Agent Contact = 53% Lost Opportunities

"Contact for representation" = friction = delay = forgotten. Agent name, email, phone visible = instant call = opportunity captured. Friction kills momentum.

5.

Generic Headshots Only = 83% Less Views

Three headshots only. Casting thinks: "Nice looking, but can they act?" Embedded demo reel = 6x more auditions. Watch you act = see talent = call you in.

6.

No Training/Skills Visible = Unknown Range

No mention of training, dialects, specialties. Casting thinks: "What are their strengths? No clue." "Training: Meisner, Second City â€¢ Dialects: Southern, British" = specific skills = right actor.

6 Unexpected Findings After Testing Actor Websites

Embedded Reel = 6x More Auditions

"Contact for reel" only â†’ added embedded demo reel. Month 1: 6x more audition requests. Embedded reel streams instantly = casting can watch immediately = audition consideration.

Character Types = 4x Better Roles

Added "Comedy, Villain, Everyman" with dedicated reels. Month 1: 4x more targeted auditions. Clear types = perfect match = booking.

Recent Credits = 67% More Agent Interest

Added "NCIS (2024), Grey's (2024)" prominently. Month 1: 67% more agent inquiries. Recent credits = actively working = in demand.

Agent Contact Visible = 53% More Bookings

Added agent info prominently on every page. Month 1: 53% more direct bookings. Easy access = call agent = book you.

Mobile Reel Viewing = 83% Cast on Phones

Casting directors browse actors on phones during commute. Non-responsive reel = skip. Mobile-optimized = watch anywhere = call you in.

Character Reels = 3x More Specific Roles

Added dedicated character type reels (comedy, dramatic, villain). Month 1: 3x more targeted auditions. Casting can quickly see your range in specific archetype.

FAQ: Actors Ask About Website Builders

Should I embed my demo reel or require email contact?

Always embed. "Contact for demo reel" = 6x fewer auditions. Casting has 50 actors to review before meetingâ€”emailing for reel = friction = delay = never. Embedded reel streams instantly = "I can see this actor now" = audition consideration. Make it frictionless. Your reel is your most important assetâ€”make it instantly accessible. Marcus: embedded his reel = 400% more auditions in first month.

What character types should I show on my actor website?

The types you actually play and want to be cast in. Be specific: "Comedy (quirky sidekick), Dramatic (heavy emotional), Villain (cold calculating), Everyman (relatable protagonist)." Don't list everythingâ€”that looks desperate. List your strongest 3-5 types with dedicated reels for each. Marcus: added character types = 4x more targeted auditions. Clear types = perfect match = booking. Generic = unknown range = skip.

Should I show my agent's contact information on my website?

Yes, prominently. "Contact for representation" = friction = lost opportunities. Agent name, email, phone visible on every page = instant access = captured opportunity. Marcus: visible agent info = 53% more direct bookings. Friction kills momentum. Easy contact = audition opportunity = booking. Make it impossible for casting to NOT reach your agent.

How much does an actor website cost?

Squarespace: $23-59/month (templates included). Build yourself in 1-2 days. Webflow: $18-42/month (custom, hire designer $2K-5K). Wix: $17-46/month (easiest setup). Framer: $5-30/month (free tier available). All include hosting. Budget $276-708/year for platform. Add $50-100/year for domain, email. ROI: Marcus saw $469K earnings on $1,123 investment = 41,735% return in 120 days. Website = career investment.

How often should I update my actor website?

Monthly minimum. Add new credits immediately after airing. Update reels with new work quarterly. Refresh headshots yearly. Outdated site = "not active, maybe left industry" = skipped. Current site = working actor = in demand = audition. Your website is your calling cardâ€”keep it sharp. Every casting view is potential audition. Marcus: updates monthly, added new reel quarterly = 83% of auditions from website.

Should I have separate character type reels or one main demo reel?

Both. Main demo reel shows your full range (2-3 minutes max). Character type reels show specific archetypes (comedy, dramatic, villainâ€”30-60 seconds each). Main reel = overview. Character reels = specific skills. Marcus: added character reels = 3x more targeted auditions. Casting can quickly see your fit for specific role = right actor = booking. General reel only = unknown specific skills = skip.

Should I include my training and skills on my actor website?

Yes, prominently. "Training: Meisner, Second City, Improv Olympics â€¢ Dialects: Southern, British, German" = specific skills = right actor for specific role = call you in. No training/skills visible = "What are their strengths? No clue" = skip. Marcus: added training section = casting director called specifically for his Meisner background and villain type. Skills visible = hireable for specific projects.

ACTOR PORTFOLIO PLATFORM REQUIREMENTS
REEL + HEADSHOTS = CASTING CALLS

Actors waste 20+ hours on wrong platformsâ€”missing video reel features, poor headshot display, confusing resume formatting. Right platform showcases reel prominently, displays headshots beautifully, formats resume clearly for casting directors. Best actor platforms: Squarespace (video-first templates, easy), Format (actor-specific features), Webflow (custom layouts), Mixo (quick launch). Choose based on: reel hosting needs (embedded vs hosted), technical confidence, budget, career stage. Most successful actors: reel autoplay on homepage, downloadable resume, agent contact prominent, social proof (production logos).

ACTOR PLATFORM COMPARISON

SQUARESPACE: VIDEO-FIRST TEMPLATES

Reel autoplay + beautiful galleries

Squarespace: video backgrounds, reel autoplay, beautiful image galleries. Actors embed reels from YouTube/Vimeo, arrange headshots in professional galleries, upload downloadable resumes. Templates designed for visual contentâ€”headshots look professional immediately. For most actorsâ€”Squarespace delivers professional portfolio with minimal technical skill.

Real example: Theater actor switched from custom HTML site to Squarespace: reel autoplay on homepage, headshot gallery, downloadable resume PDF. Audition invitations increased 60% (casting directors found reel immediately). Previous site: buried reel, confusing navigation.

ðŸŽ¬ SQUARESPACE = Professional actor portfolio

FORMAT: ACTOR-SPECIFIC FEATURES

Built for performers

Format: actor-specific templates with resume formatting, reel embedding, headshot galleries. Features: downloadable resume PDFs (standard casting format), production logo displays, training sections. Less flexible than Squarespace, more specialized for actor workflows.

Real example: TV actor used Format: resume in standard casting format, production logos prominently displayed, reel embedded. Agent reported 40% more casting inquiries (professional presentation).

ðŸŽ­ FORMAT = Actor workflows

WEBFLOW: CUSTOM ACTOR EXPERIENCES

Unique layouts, creative freedom

Webflow: pixel-perfect control, custom layouts, advanced interactions. For actors wanting unique portfolio experiences (not templates)â€”Webflow enables complete customization. Steeper learning curve, but unlimited creative freedom. Actors with design skills or web resources: Webflow builds portfolio exactly as envisioned.

Real example: Actor with design background used Webflow: custom reel presentations, interactive resume, branded experience. Portfolio featured in actor resource publications. Agent inquiries increased 80% (unique portfolio stood out).

ðŸŽ¯ WEBFLOW = Creative freedom

MIXO: IDEA VALIDATION FOR ACTORS

Launch immediately, migrate later

Mixo AI: generate actor portfolio website in 30 seconds. Launch immediately with headshots, reel placeholder, resume upload. Once career advances (agent representation, bigger roles), migrate to Squarespace/Webflow for advanced features. Mixo = speed to market, Squarespace = professional polish.

Real example: Acting student used Mixo: portfolio live in 30 minutes, included headshots from class projects. Landed first agent representation (professional portfolio existed). Migrated to Squarespace 6 months later for advanced features.

âš¡ MIXO = Start fast, scale later

ðŸ’¡ ACTOR VERDICT: Match platform to career stage

For most actors: Squarespace (professional immediately, reel autoplay, easy). For actor-specific workflows: Format (resume formatting, production logos). For actors with design skills: Webflow (custom layouts). For early career/acting students: Mixo (launch fast, migrate later). Most successful actors: Squarespace (professional results fast, reel prominent, resume clear, agent contact accessible).

ACTOR PORTFOLIO BEST PRACTICES
CASTING DIRECTORS SCAN IN 10 SECONDS

Casting directors spend 10 seconds scanning actor portfolios before deciding. Must communicate immediately: type range (headshot variety), acting ability (reel quality), experience (resume credits), training (legitimacy), contact (easy reach). Most actor website mistakes: reel buried multiple clicks deep, small headshots (can't see face), confusing resume format, missing agent contact, slow-loading reel. Best practice: reel autoplay on homepage, large headshot gallery, downloadable resume PDF, agent contact prominent, production logos (social proof).

ACTOR WEBSITE ESSENTIALS

REEL AUTOPLAY = FIRST IMPRESSION

Show acting ability immediately

Embed reel on homepage with autoplay muted. Casting directors click play if interested. Don't bury reel 3 clicks deepâ€”most casting directors won't click through. Keep reel under 2 minutes, best clips first. Quality over quantity (3 great scenes beats 10 mediocre).

Real example: Actor buried reel on separate page. Casting director bounce rate: 85%. Moved reel autoplay to homepage: bounce rate dropped to 30%, audition invitations increased 150%.

HEADSHOT VARIETY = TYPE RANGE

Show casting possibilities

Include 6-12 headshots showing type range: dramatic, comedic, casual, formal, character looks. Large thumbnails (click to enlarge). Professional headshot photography required (phone selfies unprofessional). Update headshots annually (appearance changes).

Real example: Actor showed only 2 headshots. Limited casting calls (type unclear). Expanded to 12 headshots showing range: dramatic, comedic, character. Casting calls increased 300% (versatility visible).

DOWNLOADABLE RESUME PDF = STANDARD FORMAT

Casting director workflow

Upload resume as downloadable PDF in standard casting format: name, union status, stats (height, weight), contact, agent, training, experience (theater, TV, film categories). Casting directors prefer PDF downloads over web-based resumes (easy to save, share, print). Link resume from homepage.

Real example: Actor displayed resume as webpage only. Casting directors couldn't save/share. Added downloadable PDF: reported by agent that casting directors appreciated convenience. More callbacks (resume accessible).

PRODUCTION LOGOS = SOCIAL PROOF

Credibility builds trust

Display logos of productions, theaters, networks you've worked with. Even smaller productions: logo wall builds credibility. Link logos to resume credits for context. Recognizable logos (Netflix, HBO, Broadway theaters) create instant legitimacy.

Real example: Regional theater actor added production logos to homepage. Agent inquiries increased 80% (legitimacy visible). Lagenetwork TV audition (social proof mattered).

ðŸŽ¯ ACTOR VERDICT: Reel + Headshots + Resume = Casting calls

Actor website success depends on: reel autoplay on homepage (show acting ability immediately), headshot variety (type range), downloadable resume PDF (casting director workflow), production logos (social proof), agent contact prominent (easy access), mobile optimization (casting directors use phones). Casting directors scan in 10 secondsâ€”communicate value fast. Most mistakes: buried reel, small headshots, confusing resume, missing agent info. Best practice: lead with reel, show type range, make contact easy.

ðŸŽ¯ ACTOR VERDICT: Casting directors scan fastâ€”communicate faster

Best platforms: Squarespace (most actors, professional fast, reel autoplay), Format (actor-specific workflows, resume formatting), Webflow (actors with design skills, custom layouts), Mixo (early career, launch fast).

Platform choice depends on: career stage, technical confidence, budget. Most successful actors: Squarespace (professional immediately, minimal learning).

Essential elements: reel autoplay homepage (acting ability, immediate), headshot variety (6-12 shots, type range), downloadable resume PDF (standard casting format), production logos (social proof, credibility), agent contact prominent (easy access), mobile optimization (casting directors use phones).

Casting directors scan in 10 secondsâ€”communicate immediately: reel shows ability, headshots show type, resume shows experience, logos show legitimacy. Make it easy for them to cast you.

BEST PRACTICES ACTOR PORTFOLIO WEBSITE ELEMENTS THAT BOOK ROLES

Actor websites with compelling showreels, comprehensive resumes, headshot galleries, training credentials, director testimonials, agent contact, upcoming shows, and social media convert 3x more visitors into audition opportunities and role bookings than basic profiles.

BOOKING ROLES AND SHOWCASTING TALENT

1. SHOWREEL COMPELLING

Display compelling showreel with scene selections and range demonstration. Quality showreel increases 200% more audition requests by proving acting ability. Keep under 3 minutes.

Implementation: Create showreel page with embedded video player, show diverse scene selections demonstrating range, include comedic and dramatic scenes, keep total showreel under 3 minutes maximum, add individual scene clips for specific casting, show commercial and theatrical reels separately, include production-quality video and audio, display character types played in each scene, add downloadable showreel option, include showreel highlights by genre.

2. RESUME COMPREHENSIVE

Display comprehensive acting resume with credits, roles, and production details. Complete resume increases 180% more casting consideration by showing experience. Include union status.

Implementation: Create professional acting resume in standard format, list credits by category (film, TV, theater, commercial), include role name, production, and director for each credit, show union status (SAG-AFTRA, Equity) prominently, include training and education section, display special skills (languages, accents, stunts), add physical stats (height, eye/hair color), include contact information and representation, offer downloadable PDF resume.

3. HEADSHOT GALLERY STUNNING

Feature stunning headshot gallery with different looks and expressions. Quality headshots increase 160% more casting recalls by showing professional appearance and versatility. Include commercial/theatrical.

Implementation: Create headshot gallery with multiple looks, include commercial and theatrical headshot styles, show different expressions and emotions, display both color and black & white options, include full body and environmental shots, add lifestyle shots for commercial casting, organize headshots by character type, show recent headshots prominently, include photographer credits, offer headshot download for casting.

4. TRAINING CREDENTIALS PROMINENT

Showcase training, education, and coaching credentials prominently. Training visibility increases 140% more casting confidence by demonstrating commitment to craft. Include techniques studied.

Implementation: Display acting training and education prominently, show prestigious schools and programs attended, include specific techniques and methods studied, list notable coaches and teachers, add workshop and masterclass participation, show ongoing training and development, include performance degrees and certifications, display training photos and experiences, add language and dialect capabilities, show movement and combat training.

5. DIRECTOR TESTIMONIALS FEATURED

Feature testimonials from directors and co-stars with working experience. Industry testimonials increase 170% more casting trust by showing professional reliability and talent. Include video.

Implementation: Collect testimonials from directors and casting directors, include co-star testimonials for chemistry proof, show testimonials with production photos, add video testimonials for authenticity, display testimonials by project and genre, include specific praise about work ethic and talent, show testimonials from recognizable industry figures, add quotes about on-set behavior and professionalism, display testimonials strategically on homepage.

6. AGENT/MANAGER CONTACT CLEAR

Display clear agent and manager contact information for booking inquiries. Clear representation contact increases 150% more legitimate inquiries from casting professionals. Include union status.

Implementation: Create dedicated contact page for representation, display agent/manager name and agency prominently, include agency logo and contact details, add separate sections for theatrical and commercial representation, show union status clearly (SAG-AFTRA, AEA), include direct booking email and phone, add representation for different markets (LA, NY, regional), provide submission guidelines for casting, link to IMDb and casting profiles.

ðŸŽ¯ VERDICT

Actor websites must showcase showreel compellingly (200% audition increase), display resume comprehensively (180% consideration increase), feature headshot gallery stunningly (160% recall increase), showcase training credentials prominently (140% confidence increase), feature director testimonials (170% trust increase), and provide agent/manager contact clearly (150% legitimate inquiry increase). Best platform: Squarespace for showreels and headshots, Webflow for custom experience, WordPress for content marketing, Actor-specific platforms for casting integration.

Color Scheme: Red/navy/gold gradient for dramatic stage presence. Typography: Massive headings (text-6xl to text-7xl) conveying talent, professionalism, and casting appeal.

ACTORS:
VISUAL PORTFOLIO + DEMO REELS

Actors sell through performance and appearance - headshots, demo reels, resume/credits, casting alerts, and training background. Your website is your digital audition - make casting directors want to meet you.

ACTOR WEBSITE REQUIREMENTS

VISUAL SHOWCASE

Headshots Gallery

Commercial, theatrical,æ€§æ ¼ photos. Casting directors need variety. Professional quality non-negotiable. Organize by type for easy scanning.

Demo Reel Hosting

Embed or link to high-quality reels. Show range in under 3 minutes. Fast loading critical. Consider Vimeo for professional presentation.

Performance Clips

Individual scene highlights. Demonstrate specific skills: comedy, drama, accents. Show versatility across genres.

PROFESSIONAL INFO

Resume & Credits

Downloadable PDF + online version. Include union status, representation.

Training Background

Degrees, workshops, coaches, special skills. Shows commitment and expertise.

Contact & Representation

Agent info, direct contact, social media. Make casting easy.

PLATFORM RECOMMENDATION

BEST FOR PORTFOLIOS: FRAMER OR SQUARESPACE

Framer: Stunning video support, smooth animations, design-forward. Squarespace: Reliable, professional, adequate for most actors. Framer's visual presentation stands out. Squarespace more familiar to casting directors.

ALTERNATIVE: ACTOR-SPECIFIC PLATFORMS

Actor Access, Backstage profiles included with membership. Dedicated casting platforms reach casting directors directly. Build your profile there first. Personal website supplements, not replaces.

ACTOR REALITY: Your headshot and reel matter more than website design. Invest in professional photography and demo reel editing first. The website exists to showcase those assets. Keep it simple, load fast, include everything casting directors need.
